awd_titl_txt: Defense amplification and priming in Arabidopsis
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants develop with a high degree of plasticity: their growth and ability to resist different stresses depends on their history and the current environment. Ubiquitous components of the environment are microbes, some of which promote plant health (stimulate growth and immunity) and others of which cause disease. Unlike humans, plants lack specialized circulating cells that provide immunity. Instead, plants use a chemical-based immune system. Specifically, natural chemical signals that plants produce confer protection against disease-causing microbes. Upon infection, some of these signals are transported throughout the plant to provide immunity. This project investigates how plant chemical signals and the cellular machinery needed for responding to them confer protection to plants against harmful microbes. Students will work in teams and be trained in experimental methods and data interpretation. The findings from this project could lead to commercialization of these natural immune-modulating chemicals for plant protection. The project will expose diverse high school and community members to emerging concepts in signaling and scientific research in general through workshops, lab work and community events. The Principal Investigator will develop a mentoring workshop to help other faculty recruit retain and train under-represented minority students.

Plant diseases reduce crop yield and quality. This project will elucidate mechanisms of defense priming and signal amplification that are essential for effective whole plant immunity and identify bioactive metabolites that can be commercialized for plant protection. Postdoctoral scholars will be trained in the interpretation and utilization of the latest molecular, cellular, proteomic approaches as well as techniques for metabolite analysis and will also learn mentoring skills. Aim 1 discerns how a key aminotransferase's different metabolite products control immune receptor levels and signaling outputs, respectively. The molecular basis for receptor regulation and how ligand-stimulated signaling steps are amplified will be examined. Aim 2 focuses on AZI1 and EARLI1, proteins that traffic between the site of priming signal generation and other sites. Their sites of action, targeting/trafficking mechanism and regulation by posttranslational modification and protein-protein interactions during establishment of systemic immunity will be elucidated. Aim 3, performed by undergraduate and high school students, will assess the roles of new systemic immunity protein candidates.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit 

Plants are subject to diseases that can greatly impact their survival and quality. An interesting feature of plants is that they show plasticity, meaning they can sense their environment (including the presence of microbes) and change their form and chemical properties. Sometimes these changes confer resistance to a various diseases and/or enable the plant to grow bigger. These changes require the movement of specific plant-made chemicals from one part of a plant to another. This project characterized the properties of plants that set the potential to resist disease and respond to different microbes that either promote health or cause damage. Specifically, the project showed how and where components of plant cells generate and mobilize chemical signals that confer beneficial properties of disease resistance and improved growth and health. It also developed and validated a general approach to discovering important cellular components that are needed for these beneficial properties. 

Broader of impacts:

This project established that:

(1)   The outer layer of cells of a single plant leaf can generate a chemical signal(s) that confers resistance to disease at the whole plant level. This points to a new idea about where key signals are generated and how they are mobilized. Since these cells are highly accessible, strategies can be developed to use this knowledge to promote plant health.

(2)   Depending on where a chemical arises within a plant, it can either be directly mobilized from one leaf to another and sensed to evoke a response or it can cause a chemical relay (one chemical causes the production and movement of another chemical) from the root to the upper part of the plant. This knowledge will propel the search for new chemicals that are mobilized from the root to the shoot to confer beneficial properties to the plant.

(3)   Plants utilize a suite of specialized proteins that target the part of the cell that generates key chemical signals. Many of these proteins play multiple roles in interactions with microbes that colonize roots to promote growth or infect leaves to cause disease. This knowledge can be used to breed plants of economic value to have enhanced disease resistace and improved growth properties.

In addition to the principal investigator, the project had 27 contributors, including high school and college students, PhD students, postdoctoral scholars, and a visiting professor; 8 of the contributors belong to groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. Many trainees are now in the scientific workforce doing research or getting additional training. Together, the team produced the research products (publications), disseminated the results at scientific meetings and did outreach to young people at conferences attended by members of underrepresented groups and teachers. The net result was to broaden participation in STEM and prepare a diverse group of people to participate in the scientific workforce. Findings from this project were also incorporated into a college course on plant development.
